summary: Dave Seville (Jason Lee), the Chipmunks (Justin Long, Matthew Gray Gubler, Jesse McCartney) and the Chipettes are taking a luxury cruise to the International Music Awards. Of course, Alvin cannot resist the urge to create havoc, and the singing rodents soon find themselves marooned on a seemingly deserted island. While Dave and an unlikely ally launch a search, Alvin and company discover that they are not alone on the island, as they first thought.

reviews.content: Honestly this entire franchise is so underrated like the tomato meter for this movie isn't deserved. When I watch these movies I'm never bored and the plot has something to do with each character's personality like Alvin wants his family to be respected even he doesn't show that very much, Simon is in love with Jannette and really wants to fit in but he's  easy to be picked on, and Theodore is DEATHLY AFRAID OF EAGLES! He shows this fear due to Toby telling him his family would die if an eagle picked up the chipmunks accidentally scaring him. Theodore becomes obsessed with meerkats and thinks that he should live with meerkats due to him being body shamed and thinks he doesn't fit in. Brittany is a great character because she shows she cares about her sisters and believes no one should be a lead but all of them are lead singers but Ian doesn't approve and influences her to be a leader practically forcing her to be a lead singer. Overall this movie didn't deserve the ratings it got. Alvin the Chipmunks: the Squeakquel was not a hidden gem but a hidden diamond. I think that since this movie was made for kids critics didn't really pay attention to the movie and gave it a bad rating because it's Alvin and the Chipmunks. You can really see how hard people worked on this movie just for people to say it's bad and walk away.
A very cheap low effort film
This was my favorite film when I was little, the songs were good, David cross is back and my favorite character was Simon's Jungle form it was my childhood.
The best of the 4 live-actions, since there's the most character growth/challenges in general. If you look at it more deeply, there is a great story being told- metaphorically as well!
I honestly don't get the criticism, it's a fun and lighthearted movie, with adorable characters and a nice growth of characters, with the right amount of jokes. Very enjoyable, loved it.

I never saw these movies in a long time, like other people, i either seemed to like or hate this movie along with other Chipmunks flicks. I'm not saying i like nor hate any of these movies, but i feel like i should move on from Alvin And The Chipmunks. Not their Christmas song, i like it, but the films i should possibly move on from. This was honestly one of the best movies that I have seen in a LONG time. It was a truly "laugh out loud" comedy with humor for all ages. I was inspired by main character, Ian Hawke, to be myself and never give up on my dreams. Don't even get me started on the costume designers for this movie. They were absolutely FABULOUS. My favorite piece was Ian's majestic bird costume. I am truly thankful to the writers of this film because before this franchise, I honestly had lost all hope for Hollywood. Alvin brings so much character to the big screen, Simon brings the brains, and Theodore brings great representation to all overweight chipmunks.

I actually used to unironically like these movies back when I was an idiot with no taste. I laughed at them and not sarcastically or out of pity. Even back in 2011, part of me felt that it wasn't as entertaining as the last two. Guess a juvenile parody of Cast Away wasn't trendy with the kids. Lowest common denominator fare that's one of the laziest films I've ever seen that couldn't be more blatantly screaming "Money, dear boy" if it had Laurence Olivier (or rather, a CGI likeness of him which is most definitely not a reference to a movie released in 2004 that did the CGI resurrection thing years before Star Wars did it) in it. There's a reason why I REALLY didn't want to write these reviews.

Although "Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked" was pretty unrealistic, it relates a lot to real life by distributing some wonderful messages throughout the fantastic plot.
All of the characters were unique, and it was very well directed by Mike Mitchell. It was also brilliantly written by Glenn Berger & Jonathan Aibel. 
As with all the previous movies, the performances really need to improve. I also hate when Jason Lee (Dave) yells. It sounds really cheesy. I don't think this sequel was as good as the first movie (Mainly because it was a bit boring), but it was ok. After all, it did end with a pretty catchy song!
So overall, this was an ok movie with some unique messages to offer. :)
The backgrounds are slightly better, but that isn't enough for this still being terrible.

18/100 - I don't know how these films keep getting made. The first Alvin and the Chipmunks movie was bad enough. The sequel was a disaster. This is no better. Juvenile comedy, juvenile characters, and juvenile production values all come to a head here. Anyone who has their kid asking them to see this should direct them towards literally anything outside of this franchise because it would be leagues better. I regret putting my time into this, a third installment of a franchise that shouldn't have had a second.

A series that truly shows that this should have never been a series.

Usually whenever a trilogy is formed, I'm always very interested how it will turn out. The 1st one should be the best, the 2nd is not that great, but the third redeems itself. Truly, this movie failed that idea of trilogy's. 

When I first watched this, I was surprised to see how quickly the movie got. I understand that the ship was important, but I felt like their was no true dynamic as to why out of all things it needed to be a ship. I understand that the movie was built for kids, but there's many other kid movies out there like "Despicable Me" and "The Lego Movie" that were great for all ages. The plot became so week as soon as they got on the island that I fast-forward until the end, seeing that was truly nothing special and very predictable. The chipmunks although are always a pleasure to see, but when the story is predictable, then the movie just fails. 

Knowing that Chris Miller from "The Lego Movie" will be working on the next installment of the series makes me feel really confident that the movies will be back on track as to how good the first movie was. 

F

By the way no one cares about Jeanette enough for her to be saved. Theodore and David Cross were the only things remotely tolerable about this Chippy Dippy Crapfest.

Best of the 3 for ages 7+

Okay, let's all think back to the first trailer of the first movie of this trilogy. It hurts, but try.

It opens with a montage of screaming rock fans through the ages, building up like a documentary of some classic rock legend, or some overdue comeback tour. Then you found out it was CGI chipmunks. They screech at you with helium fueled voices, and the whole thing ends when Alvin eats Theodore's shit.

Consider that. They blind you with used spectacle and feel you their shit. The metaphor is palpable.

And now? They got away with three of them. I want you all to remember, this was all your fault. They told you what you were getting on day one, and you bought it anyway.  I blame you, because they didn't film this crap on MY dollar.

Excellent Animation + Comedy + Family + Fiction Movie.......................................

With an all-new story, a cute script full of funny dialogue, a great cast that returns once again featuring Jason Lee as Dave Seville, David Cross as Ian Hawke and the voices of Justin Long as Alvin, Matthew Gray Gubler as Simon, Jesse McCartney as Theodore, Christina Applegate as Brittany, Anna Farris as Jeanette and Amy Poehler as Eleanor along with the addition of Jenny Slate as Zoe, good directing by Mike Mitchell, perfect songs, hilarious scenes and sequences and a fantastic pace and flow, Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked is another fun adventure you'll enjoy over and over again with Alvin and the gang.

There is something about harmonizing a cappella chipmunks that brings a smile to your face. It's hard to resist. Another good installment to the Chipmunk saga. I actually liked this better than the Squeakal. It compares to the first film in quality, only this one doesn't have that holiday motif. A goo fun film for the whole family. The soundtrack is entertaining, with mash ups combining songs you would've never imagined would go together. Who would've ever thought in 2011, Gloria Estefan's Conga would be remixed with a remixed version of an old Italian song? In this movie we watch the Chipmunks stranded on an island. Granted the things they construct out of bamboo and coconuts make Gilligan's Island seem realistic--but then again, this is a movie about a man who is raising six talking chipmunks as children. They even pay homage to "Cast Away" (2000). Simon's transformation into "Simone" is entertaining, but was this perhaps an attempt at competing with "Puss 'n boots" (2011)? Interesting nonetheless. This movie is fun to watch.
Good but not the best 93%

Yet another movie (after Spy Kids 4D) that I'm embarrassed to say I've seen. I'm not kidding when I say this movie makes me want to commit suicide. I guess I can see why some enjoyed the first one, but how the hell could you like this?! Why does this movie exist? Really? Why? I'll tell you why, to make a shitload of money, that's why. Ugg, everything is absolutely depressingly bad in this movie. The jokes are terrible, and oh my god could those damn chipmunks be any more annoying?! Really, I want to go and hide. It's a movie I'm embarrassed to say I watched, like I said before. Then again, I didn't watch it on my own free will, so I guess I'm not quite as embarrassed then if I decided to watch it myself. Either way though, this movie is terrible, so stay away. Ps- parents, if you're going to have a family movie night, be sure to make the flick an old 90s Disney and Hayao Miyazaki film. Ok. I don't care what the kids want. Tell them they can't watch this shit because it's for their own good. Literally, it kills brain cells. Fuck, fuck, fuck! I'm mad just thinking about this movie.

Oh, once more, slapstick galore, with everyone's "favorite" furry friends. Surprisingly, the movie isn't half bad. Yah the plot was simplistic. Yah the jokes would hit as often as they would miss and of course, the ending was a bit too preachy on values. But, the novelty of seeing all these little chipmunks scurrying about hasn't worn out yet for me. The kid in me loved it and I'm not ashamed to say it was a fun ride.

Overall: Good family film. Slapstick galore. Run of the mill plot, acting etc, but fun to watch and enjoyable nevertheless.

The first movie was quite deep, had a lot of emotional moments and was a lot of fun. The second one was focused more on the fun part rather than the emotions. This is another step in the not quite so well-picked direction. A lot of silly fun, limited deep and emotional stuff. Could have been worse but then it could have been a whole lot better. The overall experience is fortunately still watchable but should there ever be another chipmunk movie, let's hope it goes back to it's roots.

This wasn't that good. Obviously it's a kid movie, but I found the other two films to be enjoyable. This was pretty dull. There first twenty minutes was good, but after the whole shipwreck it just got really boring. Also, I did not like what they did with the lady on the island. She was definitely crazy and tried to harm one of the chipmunks, yet they got over this way too quickly (this was not really becoming for a children's movie when it comes to enslaving little chipmunks). I enjoyed the song covers, but the movie was not worth watching again.

The film is cute, but not the greatest. It reminded me a little of Cast Away, 6 Days 7 Nights, and Madagascar. Jason Lee is always great as Dave in all of the films. My name is Anthony Aranda from Kids First!  and I am reviewing a really funny movie called âAlvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked.â? This was awesome because there is a lot of action in the movie and everything the chipmunks and Chipettes do is so funny.
This movie is all about Dave, the chipmunks, and the Chipettes who go on vacation and have a really big adventure. They go on a cruise ship and Alvin keeps causing lots of trouble on the ship (like always). Alvin comes up with a really great idea to fly on top of a kite. All of the chipmunks and Chipettes are holding the kite while Alvin is flying but the wind picks up too hard. They start to fly away and Simon tries to help by tying the kite to Daveâ(TM)s chair (while he is sleeping). This still doesnâ(TM)t work and the chair and the chipmunks start to move down the deck of the ship. Eventually, the kite slips off the chair and the chair flips over. Dave wakes up to see the chipmunks and the Chipettes fly away on the kite.
Some of the main characters in the movie are Dave, the chipmunks (Alvin, Simon, and Theodore), the Chipettes (Eleanor, Jeanette, and Brittany), Zoe, and Ian. My favorite character is Alvin because he is always having fun and causing lots of trouble. I also like him because in the end he learns that he can still have fun while being responsible.
My favorite part in the movie is when the chipmunks and Chipettes meet Zoe on the stranded island. She invites them to meet her friends and when they get there they see that her friends are a bunch of sports balls.  Itâ(TM)s really funny because it seems like she is a little crazy since she has been on the island for so long. We figure out later that there are spiders on the island that change a personâ(TM)s personality and make them act differently. Later in the movie Simon gets bit by one of the spiders and then he starts acting like someone else. It is really funny. 
I would recommend this movie for all ages because it is super funny and there was no violence or parts that would scare anyone. It also shows how much family means and that most families would do anything for each other.
The scenery is great to look at, but minus that, Chipwrecked is too inane and formulaic.
The best of the trilogy. Hope there will be more.
I dont care what anyone says... I giggled and guffawed.  It reminded me of my childhood... I did begin to wonder where Miss Miller was, though! If you are child-like as I am, you will love it!

Alvin and his cohorts have made a splash in 2007 and continue to belly-flop ever since. This time, the sixtet of super annoying squirrels (I know they are chipmunks, I will call them squirrels to mess with their heads) go onto a cruise ship in order to perform at the International Music Awards. When Alvin's fun turns into fail, he and the other five menaces to society end up on a desert island and their adoptive father Dave (Jason Lee) and arch nemesis Ian Hawke (David Cross) looking for them, for opposite reasons, obviously.

After suffering through the first two "munkin'" annoying pictures, I cringed at the first feeling of renting this one, but I did and I want my money back. Honestly, how could any human being actually LIKE this franchise. It boggles the munkin' mind.

I admit that at first Alvin, Simon and Theodore were cute in the first movie, but they went from cute, to tolerable, to completely annoying. I'd like to see a fourth movie... when they get rabies and die.

But I commend the series for being consistent... consistently sucking! The actors suck, the visuals suck, all but two jokes in the entire franchise (two of which are in the third movie) suck and of course kids everywhere will think that this movie sucks.

The only good thing about this movie was... it ended.

1/2 out of ****
FINAL VERDICT: 5%

"Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked" isn't particularly good or bad, and as a kid's movie, you can do a lot worse. At least the Chipmunks look really good on blu-ray. (Blu-ray, August 6, 2012)

People usually hate my taste in movies, so this one is no exception. I don't like the cliche movies hollywood pukes out these days. Alvin and the Chipmunks was created by a guy and a tape deck in the 50's. Back when a guy could do something like that. He had a family and a job and made something in his basement. This movie is much better than the first in the series, but that's not saying much.

The musical score, singing, and animated choreaography are quite good, but Jason Lee's performance as Dave is only slightly more convincing than his other efforts as the devoted father of these English-(and French)-speaking rodents.

Chipwrecked is a completely acceptable and mostly engaging family movie, but don't look for it to generate any academy awards.  I admit that I wasn't watching the clock to see how much longer it was going to last, but the sets were pathetic while the Zoe character had perfect clothes and hair, even though we were supposed to believe she had been alone on an uninhabited island for ten years. In fact, Chipwrecked regularly and repeatedly insulted my intelligence, and that's my biggest beef with it.  Nevertheless, my nine-year-old loved it.  My twelve-year-old also found it entertaining, but I suspect her real interest was in making me watch it and proving (which she did) that it's actually better than the first one.

That's true, but that's not saying much.
